body: I'm not sure whether this still applies but for a while you had to add an engine to the console launcher's class path. Can you successfully run `.class` tests with the same configuration? Does the command line contain any complaints talking about engines?

@nicolaiparlog The command I'm using is 
`java -cp "lib/*" org.junit.platform.console.ConsoleLauncher -cp src --scan-class-path --hide-details --include-classname "^.*IT?$"`
It does work with `.class` tests, that's what we're using right now.
However, when I switch to JAR files, it does not pick up the tests.
Part of the output is:
```
INFO: Discovered TestEngines with IDs: [junit-jupiter]

Test run finished after 30 ms
[         1 containers found      ]
[         0 containers skipped    ]
[         1 containers started    ]
[         0 containers aborted    ]
[         1 containers successful ]
[         0 containers failed     ]
[         0 tests found           ]
[         0 tests skipped         ]
[         0 tests started         ]
[         0 tests aborted         ]
[         0 tests successful      ]
[         0 tests failed          ]
```
We don't scan JARs by default. Please add the path of your JAR file as argument to `--scan-class-path`.
This definitely needs better documentationâ€¦ ðŸ¤”
Hello @marcphilipp, I tried adding the path as you said (` --scan-class-path "src/testing-app-tests.jar" `), but it still did not pick it up.

Hello @marcphilipp @sbrannen @nicolaiparlog, can you confirm whether what I'm trying to do is possible? I've already tried what was suggested here but still does not work. Your help is immensely appreciated.
I am currently on vacation but will check when I return tomorrow.

I'm afraid "Classpath scanning now supports JAR files" is misleading and my previous comment was wrong. At the moment we only support resolving package selectors, not JARs as classpath roots (see #399).

So, you have to switch from `--scan-class-path` to `--select-package $YOUR_ROOT_PACKAGE`.

However, I think explicitly selecting a JAR to be scanned like I suggested above makes sense and we should add this.

@junit-team/junit-lambda What do you guys think?

> However, I think explicitly selecting a JAR to be scanned like I suggested above makes sense and we should add this.

Sounds reasonable to me.
Selecting a package that resides within a JAR file does work; I tried that yesterday. Can you please post your complete command?
